Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from three fragments) of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior glazed black; traces of two added red bands on rim; exterior: lip and upper part of handle zone glazed, with added red line; reserved below; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies this sherd as a Type 10.2.A South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-6) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-8). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The place of production of the vase was determined as probably Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.1025) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric. Schlotzhauer suggests that the sherd may belong to the same cup as British Museum 1886,0401.301 but this seems unlikely as this sherd does not have a reserved band around the interior edge of the (shorter) rim, nor do the inscriptions, as far as they are preserved, betray the same hand.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXIII, no. 245)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 663, no. 206)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 53, no. 328, p. 101, NAU 51, pl.11e-f)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.687) (Phase 3)
